ac-1.title: AC-1
ac-1.description: A humble typeface designed around ideas about respect, modesty, and authorship.

story.content: AC-1 is a typeface that acknowledges that because typography inevitably shapes meaning, there is no such thing as a neutral or objective typeface. Instead of aiming for invisibility or sterility, AC-1 asserts modesty and clarity as its guiding principles, fostering a respectful and thoughtful collaboration between type and text.

story.caption: AC-1 resists any rigid categorization, hybridizing features from multiple traditional type classifications. On one hand, touches of traditionally humanist features add an approachability that is critical of modernist sterility. On the other, its decided dedication to clarity opposes the excess and irony associated with postmodern styles.

The process of developing AC-1 reveals the iterative exploration that shaped the typeface, oscillating between precision and human-centered clarity to achieve a design that respects both typographic function and the nuances of the text it serves.

AC-1 Periodic Table Specimen demonstrates the typeface’s ability to balance the systematic rigor found in mechanical and empirical modes of objectivity with human-centered clarity, repositioning precision as an act of thoughtful communication rather than neutral detachment.
AC-1 Literary Research Specimen demonstrates the typeface’s ability to engage with emotive and subjective literary content, offering clarity that respects and honors the text it serves.

sfpc-identity.title: School for Poetic Computation
sfpc-identity.description: Giving form to alternative frameworks of computer programming with a visual identity that is itself a practice of subversive code.

media.alt: Back of CD case for hypothetical music project, Ballads
Back of CD case for hypothetical music project, Ballads
Back of CD case for hypothetical music project, Ballads
Back of CD case for hypothetical music project, Ballads
Back of CD case for hypothetical music project, Ballads
Back of CD case for hypothetical music project, Ballads

story.content:
A visual identity concept for the School for Poetic Computation (SFPC), an artist run school in New York that focuses on the intersection of art, code, hardware, and critical theory. SFPC revolves around the idea of 'poetic computation:' an alternative approach to programming that challenges the activity's traditional functions, uses, values, and assumptions. In doing this, poetic computation becomes a kind of cultural activism, recontextualizing code through critical use and misuse.

My visual identity concept aimed to give form to 'poetic computation' which I discovered could only be represented authentically through a visual identity that is, itself, a gesture of subversive programming.

story.caption: The project began with one of, if not the, most ubiquitous forms of code: text. I appropriated text-based code in order to create ASCII art.
Hand-drawn ASCII art became one form of the visual identity.
This strategy of appropriation was translated into other forms of code, such as early programmable music technology.
Appropriating early programmed music into posters.

The project also explored code in the form of abstract models, such as cellular automata. Using Processing, I programmed AutoSpell, a generative typography system that synthesizes typography and the Game of Life, a type of cellular automata.
AutoSpell was used to capture a moment of typography and imagery interacting with a live cellular automata simulation.

comparator-mirror.title: Comparator Mirror
comparator-mirror.description: Reinterpreting a painting tool from 18th century optical sciences.

media.alt: Back of CD case for hypothetical music project, Ballads
Back of CD case for hypothetical music project, Ballads
Back of CD case for hypothetical music project, Ballads

story.content: This project reconsiders the comparator mirror, a mechanical device that was invented during the rise of optics in the 18th century and was used to assist in painting realistic depictions of life, within a contemporary context. Informed both by the history of optics and by postmodern theories of subjectivity, I wanted to explore bridging the gap between notions of mechanical objectivity with contemporary theories about the subjective nature of perception and reality. The result is a reinterpreted comparator mirror that positions the optical sciences as itself a romantic, poetic form of subjectivity and sight.

story.caption: My comparator mirror features a modular, symmetrical design, inspired by the symmetries of light (reflection, refraction, etc.) and lends it a tone borrowed from historical associations between symmetry, geometry, and divinity.

story.content: It consists of three distinct parts: the Cover, the Tray, and the Frame, each of which function in the alignment and layering of images, transforming perception into a creative process.

story.caption: The Cover displays a diagram with assembly instructions and doubles as a magnetic backboard.
The Tray holds the mirror and spare magnets, convertible to a flat canvas surface.
The Frame secures all parts with magnetic points, and can be used without the Tray for oversized canvases.
I fabricated the comparator mirror using clear acrylic, which gave the rasterized graphics on the object a luminosity that speaks to light’s poetic and transcendent qualities.
I fabricated the comparator mirror using clear acrylic, which gave the rasterized graphics on the object a luminosity that speaks to light’s poetic and transcendent qualities.
Designed comparator mirror diagram.

source-material.title: Source Material
source-material.description: A publication for and by students.

story.content:
Source Material is a publication founded and led by students at ArtCenter College of Design. It celebrates interdisciplinary collaboration at the College through a community-based publication every semester, featuring submitted work by students and alumni according to a theme/topic chosen by the Source Material team.

There were no strict roles within Source Material's team, which aspired towards a non-hierarchal model of organization. For brevity, I primarily contributed to the publication as a coeditor and designer from Summer 2022 to Fall 2023, which included designing and producing publications, ephemera, artifacts, social media materials, installations, and copywriting.

Credits

Issue 03: Safe Spaces
Aldon Chen, Sean Nagao, Evelyn Luu, Rebecca Brown, Sahar Habashi, Jaiwon Lee, Nick Rheem.

Issue 04: Faces
Aldon Chen, Sean Nagao, Ruby Kim, Rebecca Brown, Sahar Habashi, Jaiwon Lee, Nick Rheem.

Issue 05: Ways of Mapping
Aldon Chen, Sean Nagao, Ruby Kim, Elliana Lee, Rebecca Brown, Nick Rheem.

story.caption: Example of publication: Issue 05: Ways of Mapping, which featured writing and maps drawn by students and alumni.

story.content:
Issue 05: Ways of Mapping introduction copy

From etchings on ancient clay tablets to Medieval atlases to Google Earth, maps have played an essential role in the way humanity has navigated, visualized, and represented the world we occupy. It is because of these functions that maps have also been historically utilized and deployed by dominant powers wanting to preserve their status quo by instantiating and reinforcing a certain dogmatic way of seeing the world.

For Issue 05: Ways of Mapping, Source Material collaborated with ArtCenter students and alumni to explore and examine how maps have influenced and continue to influence the way we witness the world around us. The publication stands as a document and a celebration of nuance and individual subjectivity, inviting new modes of cartography that emphasize each person’s singular experience of the world rather than how it’s presented to us.

story.caption: Example of publication: Issue 04: Faces, which featured writing and portraits drawn by students and alumni.

story.content:
Issue 04: Faces introduction copy

By expanding upon the timeless tradition of the self portrait, Source Material wants to inspire members of our community at ArtCenter to explore, examine, and reflect on the ways in which they perceive themselves and others. Issue 04 presents a collection of portraits, prose, poems, and prompts that document the unique ways in which identities materialize, transform, and interact in relation to one another.

story.caption: Additional ephemera and artifacts were designed and produced to accompany the publication of each issue. Example shown: key keychains for Issue 03: Safe Spaces.
Example of an additional ephemera: Geographical Anomalies Map to compliment Issue 05: Ways of Mapping ,and which reinterpreted the informational structure of traditional geographic maps.
Example of an additional artifact: Nalgene water bottle to compliment Issue 05: Ways of Mapping, which appropriated one of the earliest maps of Los Angeles.

To celebrate the release of each issue, we organized and designed a release party in conjunction with the publication. This included designing and producing signage, video projections, and various functional and interactive fixtures.
Planning for Issue 03: Safe Spaces release party installation.
Members of the Source Material team installing fixture for the Issue 03: Safe Spaces release party.
Hand-painting wall graphics for the Issue 04: Faces release party.

writing-under-from-and-beyond.title: Writing Under, From, and Beyond
writing-under-from-and-beyond.description: Printed matter designed for the community within Chris Kraus' courses at ArtCenter.

story.content: Project story is currently being edited in preparation for graduation. Please excuse the mess! :)

A series of printed matter designed while as a student of and a Teaching Assistant to Chris Kraus, author of I Love Dick. Designs were inspired by the class' unique pedagogy and the journalistic approach to personal writing that was taught by Kraus.

story.caption: Observations is a zine composed of writing and image contributions by students in Kraus’ class in Spring 2023, Investigative Fiction / Non-Fiction. Each piece of writing takes the form of a list stating a sequence of ordinary observations. The design of the zine brings the banality of the writing to the forefront, giving the zine a self-awareness that turns its ordinary nature into the super-ordinary.
I designed Observations and produced copies for the class during some of my free time over roughly one week.

Investigations was a reading event organized by Kraus’ class during Spring 2023: Investigative Fiction / Non-Fiction, in which students performed a live reading of their writing from the class. As a student in the class, I designed posters that functioned both as a way to promote the event and as takeaway mementos for the students in the class.
I also took part in reading!

For Chris Kraus’ class during Spring 2024, Writing: Investigation + Beyond, I knew it would be the last semester I would be a Teaching Assistant for the class. I noticed that during the class, some students would draw other students in sketchbooks. Inspired by the journalistic approach to writing that Chris had been teaching, I secretly reached out to these students to collaborate, gradually building a collection of everyone in the classroom over the semester that I used to design a small printed poster, Portrait of a Class, which we surprised Chris with during the last class session.

to-gary-kornblau.title: To Gary Kornblau, From Aldon Chen
to-gary-kornblau.description: Talking back to a professor for assigning homework over break.

story.content: Project story is currently being edited in preparation for graduation. Please excuse the mess! :)

Prompted by an assignment based on Bell Hook's idea of 'talking back', I decided to 'talk back' to my professor, Gary Kornblau, about how very seriously egregious it was that he decided to assign this work to be due the first day of class.
